author: ralexstokes
content: if the `gnark` code is indeed conformant then it sounds like the geth code may be out of date wrt the latest spec -- <@!211091239112671234> do you have a link to what i think is the `bls12381` package you are referencing (or whatever they mean by "geth code")?

author: ralexstokes
content: and while there may have been some minor spec updates to the BLS cryptosystem, they shouldn't really affect the BLS12-381 arithmetic that we want to get into the EVM a la EIP-2537

author: ralexstokes
content: i also lean towards the "shanghai should be a pressure-release valve fork" camp (from today's call) but it would be great to see something like 2537 soon as it unlocks a lot of interesting new use cases (and is more or less required for sharding)

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Would withdrawals replace the deposit contract?
If so, doing 2537 in conjunction would allow us to improve the deposit contract as well, right?

author: ralexstokes
content: i'm assuming it is just the `bls12381` package in geth today

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: yes

author: ralexstokes
content: i don't think we want to touch the deposit contract without very good reason

author: ralexstokes
content: there is some WIP work on withdrawals here: https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/2759

author: ralexstokes
content: basic idea is to make a "withdrawals root" (like the "deposit root" in the deposit contract today) and expose that to the evm

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: How would we unlock the ETH from the deposit contract?

author: ralexstokes
content: if we do the "change of credentials" operation referenced in that PR then we don't need userspace BLS math

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Or would we do an invalid state transition on every withdrawal?

author: ralexstokes
content: the eth can stay in the deposit contract

author: ralexstokes
content: that eth is "burned"

author: timbeiko
content: The ETH in the deposit contract isn't enough: there are also validator rewards to account for

author: ralexstokes
content: like if you sent eth to `0x0`

author: djrtwo
content: define "invalid"

author: djrtwo
content: valid is just the rules of the protocol

author: djrtwo
content: if you have a sink into the beacon chain (the dpeosit contract) and a pull out of it -- some withdrawal receipts root -- that is functionally equivalent to a deposit/withdrawal contract that did both functions together

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Hmm, It would mean that we would increase the money supply by 32 + validator rewards ETH on every withdrawal.
Just think it is not easy to explain that to the general audience

author: timbeiko
content: That's already the case, though!

author: djrtwo
content: the "money supply" is less the value in the deposit contract

author: djrtwo
content: yeah, as <@!552133098075193354> mentions, you can already have that issue if you choose to frame it that way

author: djrtwo
content: the "money supply" is beacon-chain validator balances plus EL  balances minus deposit contract balance

author: djrtwo
content: if this is really a concern, just write down the algorithm and expose the "supply" as a json rpc endpoint to make the bitcoiners happy

author: djrtwo
content: I *really* don't think it's worth the consensus and development complexity to try to make this look too clean because the bitcoiners will complain
